title: Edward Fauver
text:
Edward "Edwin" Fauver (May 7, 1875 – December 17, 1949) was an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> coach and college athletics administrator. In addition to his coaching duties, he was an athletic instructor at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a> and <a href="Wesleyan%20University">Wesleyan University</a>.
Coaching career.
Alma.
Fauver was the head football coach at <a href="Alma%20College">Alma College</a> in <a href="Alma%2C%20Michigan">Alma, Michigan</a>. He held that position for the 1899 season. His coaching record at Alma was 2–1–3.
Oberlin.
After his year at Alma, Fauvner became the head coach at <a href="Oberlin%20College">Oberlin College</a> in <a href="Oberlin%2C%20Ohio">Oberlin, Ohio</a> for five seasons, from 1900 to 1904, three of those seasons alongside his brother <a href="Edgar%20Fauver">Edgar Fauver</a>. At Oberlin, his teams generated a record of 24–15–2.
Rochester.
Fauver went on to become the head football coach and <a href="athletic%20director">athletic director</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Rochester">University of Rochester</a> in <a href="Rochester%2C%20New%20York">Rochester, New York</a>. He was the head football coach for the 1917 and 1918 seasons and achieved a record of 4–5–1. While at Rochester, he helped to form the New York State Conference of Small Colleges and the Western New York Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. On October 18, 1930, the school chose to honor him by naming the university's stadium in his honor.
